text: Here we are, gathered around
two round tables, as it were.
But let's start the conversation
by maybe making introductions,
maybe for the audience.
So we'll start with Iyad,
go ahead and introduce yourself.

- Thank you Roy, as
always, it's a pleasure.

I'm Iyad Tarazi, CEO
of Federated Wireless.

We're a software company
that is really focused
on taking the best that AWS has to offer,

and turn it into private
wireless solutions,

for the best customers,
as you're going to hear.
- Yeah, let's talk to one of those

best customers, introduce
yourself, please Bill.

- Thanks Roy, Bill Britton,
Chief Information Officer

at California State Polytechnic
University in California.
We are so big estate, we have three

polytechnics now, so
you can get lost there.

- All right, Chris,
introduce yourself please.
- Yes, thanks Roy, I'm Chris McKenna,
I lead business development for
private networks for AWS.
- Excellent, very good,

and we're here to talk
about private wireless.
So we'll start with Bill, so what is it
about private wireless that you see
as value, to someone like Cal Poly?

Right, how does introduction
of private wireless
enhanced the life, and maybe, you know,

the productivity or the
capabilities of Cal Poly?

- Well, you know, it starts
with our conversation
around going to the cloud, and the amount
of data we generate on the university.
And so that's really big for,
particularly a polytechnic,
because we have Ag, we have high tech,

we have all of those things,
all massive data generators.
And so we're pushing data around
the university, like never before, and
believe it or not, where we are,

is one of the largest
fiber hubs in the US,
but it's still just not enough

because we're limited by
the capacity on campus,

that is, our current wireless
systems and other things.
And so if you really look at what

I'm dealing with, it's
a matter of subtraction.

Everything we do on the
internet, is a subtract.

If I want to add more
data from our Ag school,
I have to subtract it from somewhere else.
And so what we really wanted in
the private 5G arena, is to look

for some solution that
is no longer detracting

from the ability to push
data, but an additive.

And not only that, it's
smart in how it does it,

so that it allows us to
pick and choose, where

and how the data is
processed, how it's moved,

how it's pushed along,
where it's computed at,
and really expand the capability
that drives us now to a digital campus,
with the proper enterprise to support it.

- Yeah, I think that
couple of things in there

were interesting to me. 
The fact that, you know,

you have a lot of different
use cases on campuses
like industrial, right, agricultural.
Ag-tech generates a lot of data.
- Absolutely.
- Where private wireless, it's not
just connectivity, but an enabler,
right, for you to do something with
the students - very, very valuable.
And so I know recently, we all saw
the announcement of this thing called

"Integrated Private
Wireless," on AWS no less.

And who better to tell
us about IPW and AWS
than Chris, so what is IPW?
- Yeah, thanks Roy, so last week
we announced a new partner program in AWS.

We're calling it, "Integrated
Private Wireless on AWS."

And the program is
designed to help customers

like Cal Poly to explore
private 5G offerings,
to explore use cases, industry verticals
where it's relevant, and learn more about

the benefits that private 5G
solutions can bring to them.
So inside that partner program,
we have Federated Wireless who
play a really important part in that.

Actually they play two
roles within the program.
One is to build into end solutions,

to take out to the market,
using pre-integrated

AWS infrastructure and
pre-integrated connectivity
and over the top application vendors,
and package all that up and take it

out to market as a single
managed services offering.
And what that does, is it breaks down kind
of three barriers to entry that

we see in the market
today, that our customers
are telling us we need to solve.
One is high upfront cost. We work to

create a managed
service offering together,

which has that cost,
spread across
the whole life of the agreement.
We work to ensure that the solutions
that are are part of that offering
are pre-integrated in AWS, so AWS pick up
the sort of heavy lift of doing all

the architectural work
and the integration work.
And what that means is that it breaks down
the complexity, but it also accelerates
time to market, which is the third problem

that we're trying to solve,
is get things out quickly.
So as we go and we address specific
industry verticals, and we go and address

the requirements of Cal
Poly and others like them,

we can create
reusable offerings

that we can then take to
customers, just like those.
And that's what the program is all about.

So that's number one
role at Federated play.
Number two is we are also working
with CSPs to create end-to-end offerings.
CSPs need solutions, integrators, SIs.
So Federated also play that role
within the program, so we're delighted
to work with Federated on that.
- Excellent, so in terms of the dual role
the Federated Wireless plays, I mean
I think it's really critical for programs

like IPW and AWS, which
is, I think, very helpful
as Chris points out, right?
Reduce the cost, reduce the complexity,

and reduce the time to
market, or time to value,
as it were, right?

Not necessarily to
market, but time to value.
So yeah, you've been in this space
for some time now, private wireless,
you clearly are experts in this space.
Given what you're seeing at Cal Poly

and other customers,
and with your partners
like AWS, what do you envision -

what do you see for
private wireless, right?

What do you see in the
next couple of years,
explosive growth perhaps?

- Oh, absolutely, we're beginning
to see the curve pick up.
We're an ecosystem company,
we're a partner enablement company,
we're a customer enablement company.
Our belief has always been the bigger
the party, the better the results.
And we believed in AWS, not just because
of technology and solutions, but also
the massive partner ecosystem they bring.
That's a huge advantage. We believe
in people like Bill to enable him,
support him in whatever he needs,
because it's the Bills of the world,
they're going to create the application,
that are going to design what's going on.
So I am not a believer that this

is one SKU, one application,
solves the world.
I'm a believer, this is about enabling
the enterprise customers at the end
of the day, to do what they need
to do in the simplest way possible.
So what do I see, I see a lot more people
following on Bill's steps, and asking Bill

for advice, which is
exactly what we're working

on now, is to create a
community around Bill,

a community around
supporting the community
that AWS is creating, enabling all
of the models that they're creating.
We're here to bring other people with us.
We all want to succeed, and the issue
is big and needs to be solved.
Customers want to manage their networks,
they want to solve their problems,
but they want to do them in the most

flexible and economic,
and secure ways.
We're here to help them.
- I think that's absolutely fair.

I think private wireless
brings that reliability

to security, that enablement
of digital use cases.
I think that's the critical thing.
I think one thing that I've learned
in this industry, is that, you know,
very, very often we look at enterprises

or organizations, you
know, historically Wi-Fi
was about connectivity, fundamentally.
But private wireless is about application

and business problems that
people want to solve, right?
And I think collectively, what we're
seeing here, is a way to solve this.

And speaking of parties,
if we want to get

on the Integrated Private
Wireless on AWS party,
where do we start, Chris?
- So I would say to enterprise customers,

one thing I didn't
mention earlier is that,

as part of this launch,
we have also launched,
I think what we call the,
"Integrated Private Wireless Portal."
This is a rich set of information
about industry verticals, about use cases,
and about the partners we have
that can deliver against those use cases.
So what I would say to enterprises is,
"Go and have a look at the portal."
There will soon be Federated Wireless

solutions on there,
and Federated solutions

are also available on our
AWS marketplace today,

which is another source
of procuring those.
- Excellent, so that's a great way
to get started, and I want to thank Iyad,

thank you, Chris, and
especially thank you Bill
for making the trip to this round table,

and hopefully you've
enjoyed the conversation,
and hopefully the audience is able to get
on that Integrated Private Wireless
on AWS, is a mouthful, band wagon, party
- IPW.
- Yeah, IPW, is that okay?

- Very good.
- That works.

- Well thank you gentlemen.
- Thank you.
- [Iyad] Thank you.
